title: Can you change my mind?
preview: I am not a big meme person, but the "Change My Mind" meme template is thought-provoking and challenging
body:
[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!-A9I!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F62a73ea0-396e-4570-a108-6c8590212166_577x432.jpeg)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!-A9I!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F62a73ea0-396e-4570-a108-6c8590212166_577x432.jpeg)

I am not really a big fan of memes.

While many memes can express quite a bit through the use of images instead of words, those same memes can also distort truth through omission or by stating something that is categorically untrue.

But the “Change My Mind” meme template strikes me differently, and its very name hints at the best way to handle disagreements: through persuasion.

There is, of course, an unanswered question with this meme. How do we get people to change their minds? Do we use force or the threat of force? Do we try to shame people into changing their minds? Do we try to use logic and reason?

Have we considered the role of letting the other person have their say as a part of persuasion? Is it possible that by asking them questions, we might get them to consider possibilities that were previously not considered?

Is it possible that our own minds might be changed in the process, that we are the ones persuaded to budge on an issue that we consider important? Is that a risk worth taking?

I think that persuasion is best whenever possible. We should all be willing to listen to each other and use logic and reason to justify our views as much as we can. There are no guarantees of success, but persuasion is the preferred practice in most situations where people don’t see eye to eye.

If I’m wrong about this…change my mind.
